images.title: Des Blenkinsopp / The Bell at Aldworth
images.caption: The Bell at Aldworth. Besides its listing and awards, the pub is also notable for having been owned and run by the same family continuously since the 18th century.

images.title: Portobello Wood, Aldworth by Andrew Smith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bluebells in Portobello Wood, Aldworth

images.title: Andrew Smith / Barley, Lowbury Hill
images.caption: Barley, Lowbury Hill. Looking down across the Aston Upthorpe Downs with their steep dry valley. In the distance are the twin wooded hilltops of Wittenham Clumps.

images.title: The Ridgeway, Aldworth, Berkshire by Oswald Bertram, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Colin Smith / South of Thurle Down
images.caption: South of Thurle Down

images.title: Graham Horn / River Thames at Streatley
images.caption: River Thames at Streatley. On the Berkshire side of the river, the Swan at Streatley forms the waterfront in front of the weir (below the photographer. The lock is further to the east (right) on the Oxfordshire side of the river. The Oxford barge (blue vessel in the middle) is a permanently moored feature and is available for hire for conferences, receptions and civil weddings.

description: This rural village in Berkshire sits just to the west of Streatley, near the border with Oxfordshire. Aldworth is a very pretty with its historic 13th century church and noteworthy Bell Inn Pub. It's a nice place to start a walk with lots of good footpaths to explore the surrounding Berkshire Downs countryside. This walk from the village heads north to pick up The Ridgeway National Trail. You'll then climb to Lowbury Hill where there's some fine views and the site of an ancient Roman Temple. The route then follows The Ridgeway east to visit neighbouring Streatley where you can enjoy a nice riverside walk along the River Thames on the Thames Path .
